Unit 2 Summative Task

K: 25%

Type of Assessment: Unit Summative

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Learning Goals:

In this unit, you should achieve the following learning goals:

  • Learn the forces that shape and influence an individual’s behaviour from the early stages of socialization and into adolescence;

  • Appreciate the changes that happen to an individual and how those changes affect the values and attitudes of society at large;

  • Recognize new trends and challenges adolescents and their families face today

  • Practice research and inquiry skills on the challenges faced by an individual at home by learning the key differences between primary and secondary sources of information

  • Choose an issue you are interested in and develop a campaign to raise awareness about it.




Ontario Curriculum Expectations

B1.1

outline and compare the key ideas of major theories used to explain social change

B1.2

describe various psychological, social, material, or cultural conditions that are used to explain social change

B1.3

explain major social science methodologies and research designs

B2.2

explain how various economic, environmental, political, or sociocultural factors

B2.3

explain various means of creating social change

C1.1

Describe population trends in Canada and around the world (e.g., rural-suburban-urban migration, the baby boom effect, differences between the demographic profiles of developed and developing nations)

C1.2

Explain concepts related to demography (e.g., replacement level, fertility rate, demographic transition), and assess the social impact of demographic change

Instructions

Step One: Review

Review the theories of adolescent development and Generational theories. 



Step Two: PLAN

After reviewing the theories of development, choose anyone from your family, friends, neighbors, or colleagues whom you can ask for a short interview.

  • Choose two interviewees ages 13-17 (as interviewee #1) and 30-50 (as interviewee #2)

  • Set a schedule for the interview and orient the interviewees. 

Step Three: Interview

During the interview, ask the following questions: 

  • At what age is a person an adult?

  • What does it mean to become an adult?

  • How many friends do you have?

  • What are your regrets in life?

  • At your age, what is your concept of happiness?

  • What do you think are the greatest challenges of your generation?

  • *You may add additional questions to your interview that you think might help you in explaining your chosen theory.



Step Four: Write

After gathering responses from your interviewees, compare and contrast their answers. Critically analyze their answers by relating and applying it to Generational Theories and/or Theories of Adolescent Development. 

Put everything together in a separate Google or Microsoft document. Make sure you comply with the following guidelines:

  • Times New Roman, 12, 1.5 spacing, 1” margins on all sides

  • Make sure it’s a 3-paragraph, 500-word essay.

  • Your final copy will be in MLA format with Works Cited Page.

Step Five: Review

Read through your essay before submitting it for marking. Use the rubric provided by your teacher as a guide in editing and finalizing your literary essay.

Step Six: Submit

Email your literary essay with this document to your teacher.

Learning Goals:

By the end of this unit, you should be able to achieve the following learning goals:

  • Describe the impact of behaviour and how ideas are constructed within the Canadian context;

  • Appreciate the current trends in Canadian society by looking at different theoretical perspectives;

  • Learn the research and inquiry skills of recording and organizing information and data as part of conducting social science research;

  • Acquire an understanding of how to engage and become involved in your school and community.

Step Two: PLAN

Consider the following idea or question in constructing your essay:

The unequal distribution of wealth and power in society promotes conflict among its members. As you might remember, Karl Marx (German philosopher and sociologist) was introduced to schools of thought in sociology. He carefully examined the inequalities between classes of society as a way of understanding who we are and the facets of our social situation. Moreover, an Italian Marxist philosopher, Antonio Gramsci, also believed that the capitalist state controlled society.

The Covid19 pandemic has exposed more flaws about our economic structures, shining light onto social inequalities under a capitalist society. For this activity, you will have to research and write a minimum of 500-word essay about the impacts of capitalism in the surge of pandemic. Primarily, answer the following question: 

a. What do you think are effects of capitalism during the pandemic? In your community? In the world as a whole?

b. How do you think capitalism affects the women and working class during the pandemic? 

c. As a youth, what can we do to empower the under privilege in times of crisis like the corona virus pandemic?

    2. Opposing argument 2 to your thesis

HSB4U

Task: Infographic about a social issue

Type of Assessment: Culminating Task (RST)

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Learning Goals:

Ontario Curriculum Expectations

A3

assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry

A3.1

assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice) 

B2. 

demonstrate an understanding of the causes and effects of social change;

B2.1 

describe ways in which influential Canadian leaders have contributed to social change (e.g., Nellie McClung, Agnes Macphail, Tommy Douglas, Lester B. Pearson, Pierre Trudeau, David Suzuki, Phil Fontaine, Roberta Jamieson, Adrienne Clarkson)

B2.2

explain how various economic, environmental, political, or sociocultural factors (e.g., global warming/climate change, environmental activism, the threat of separatism, leadership changes, pluralism) can lead to social change, and how other factors (e.g., cost, traditional values, fear of negative consequences) can create resistance to change

B2.3 

explain various means of creating social change (e.g., direct action, protest, advocacy, community organization, revolution, political activism) 

C3

demonstrate an understanding of social science theories about social deviance, and of how various responses to deviance affect individuals and society

C3.1

describe the key ideas of major social science theories related to deviance (e.g., labelling theory, social control theory, differential association theory, cultural theories)

C3.2

summarize and interpret statistics related to social deviance, discrimination, and hate crimes

C3.3

describe various methods of deterrence used within local, national, and global institutions

and societies

C3.4

explain the relationship between social panic about crime and deviance and the attention given to these issues by media, politicians, and other social groups



Instructions:

Step One: BRAINSTORMING

Type of Assessment: Culminating Task (RST)

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment of Learning

1. Choose any social issue you would want to study. 

2. Incorporate your chosen social issue to the topics we have discussed. How do you think are they related or interconnected?

Step Two: Outline your goals in creating your infographic

Your infographic should address or solve any social issue and make sure to connect it to a theory, concept, philosophies that we have discussed in our class. 

Your outline should depend on how you plan to present the information you have gathered. It could be a presentation of two opposing sides, the interconnection of concepts to each other, or a flow chart of a concept.

Step Three: Collect Data for Infographic

You may search for databases, numerical data, or articles to support your infographics. 

Step Four: Visualize the data

Choose the best chart for your purpose. If you want to inform, you may use pictograph, flowchart, donut chart. If you want to compare, try bar, pie, or stacked column charts. If you want to present change, you may use timeline or line chart. 

Step Five: Add style to your infographic design

You may use website or applications like photoshop, canva, or even as microsoft word. Experiment with using different colors, icons, fonts, and pictures. Make sure that your infographic is readable and appealing to your reader. Remember that the goal of infographics is to make an appealing presentation of an idea. 

Step six: Write your data

The infographics should have:

1. A problem or question needs to be addressed.

2. A social issue

3. Application of the concepts/theories you learned in class. 

4. Incorporate your opinion to your presentation. 

5. Simplified and comprehensible presentation of your ideas. 

6. Use MLA format in citing your references. 

Step seven: Review your work

Read through your infographics before submitting it for marking. Use the rubric provided by your teacher as a guide in editing and finalizing your proposal.

Step eight: SUBMIT

Submit your copy of the homework document and your final research proposal in your shared course folder.
